posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
No idea why everyone on /gd/ shits on this as a career.

The industry is changing, graphic design is becoming a discipline rather than a profession, industries are internalizing the skillset and in-housing their designers. As a result nobody can be "just" a graphic designer, there's little demand for external designers, they are too problematic because they lack adjacent skills.

I make print works, I'm a printer. Half of what I do is graphic design and as such I never hire an external graphic designer, but nor could I print much without having these skills myself. I design physical products, graphic design is part of my skillset as a product designer, nobody who wants chairs made will hire a graphic designer to support the fabrication of chairs, even though it is needed. They hire a product designer and just expect us to do the graphic design as part of that.

My advice, hard skills. You need hard skills to market yourself. Graphic design isn't a hard skill, bad luck, you've got to tie it to a hard skill. coding, painting, print making, carving, CNC, lazer engraving, commercial painting and decorating etc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I suspect this is because chat GPT cannot identify a single non-proprietary reference image.

This is a recognized IP issue, you can make a work of art that is "inspired" by a proprietary work if your work doesn't take elements directly from theirs and is not a "copy".

But the notable exception to this is collage, in music sample limit. Where you have not "coppied" a single image but your collage is just multiple samples from the same source. So if all the samples of Colonel Cambel come from the same IP holder, anything chat GPT generates would be a "copy" or a "collage" which would be over the sample size. These cases are constantly argued in court, but if you cannot identify a single reference which is NOT from the same IP you are basically guilty by default.

You can't copy a Salvidor Dali without permission and pass that off as your own IP. Nor can you steal elements of it, nor can you make a "collage" of a bunch of Dali images and claim the work is original.

AI is like Uber, it's blatantly breaking the law on such a scale and with such impunity that they are forcing the law to change through violation of it; it's a content piracy revolt by big tech

posts.name: Anonymous

>>458843
The color on the left is a shade of violet. Violet is typically a lighter, bluish-purple hue, and this color has that softer, blue-leaning tone.
The color on the right is a shade of purple. Purple tends to be richer and more reddish or magenta-like, and this color fits that description with its deeper, red-leaning tone.
These distinctions can vary slightly depending on personal perception and lighting, but in general, violet leans toward blue, while purple leans toward red. Does that help clarify it for you?

The outline around the letters being larger than the stroke of the letters themselves almost never looks good; at that point you may as well just make a contrasting rectangular background and lose all the squiggles.
This is especially true when the outline of the head (largest graphic element in the composition) has a red border that is *smaller* than the either the red border around the lettering or the stroke of the letters themselves...doing it that way makes no sense in the context of visual weight and balance and how those affect viewer attention.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>459650
It's better but the circular end curves make no sense and just direct your eyes to the new width discrepancies they introduce between that background and the letter forms.
The beginning and ending letter shapes are actually very conducive to a simple rectangular background banner shape with rounded corners that loosely follow the letter shapes, only one corner deviates significantly from being symmetrical...why add a completely different curve?
One other issue screwing it up is that the letter spacing is way crowded; this not only affects legibility, it also makes the outside border look unbalanced because the border area between the letters is too small by comparison.

>>459675
Agreed. The wiggly letter outlines add a wonderfully weird groove that is much better suited to the eccentric nature of this particular mascot. The advice you got to make everything corporate and smooth works in like 99.99% of brand images nowadays which thrive off of "clean" inoffensive blandness, but this weird fred guy is just the rare exception. He has too much wacky personality and needs something bold and counter-culture. Wiggly words for the win.
